Goddess of the solemn hour,</br>Let me feel thy pensive pow'r!</br>Shun my walk, vain Noise and Folly,</br>Welcome pleasing Melancholy!

Hark! the signal of the show'r</br>Whistles thro' yon ruin'd tow'r;</br>From the ivy, climbing high,</br>See the boding night-bird fly,</br>Hooting, from its omen'd breath,</br>Sounds of horror, sounds of death!—

Hark! the thunder from on high</br>Grumbles o'er the vaulted sky!</br>See the gleamy lightnings play,</br>Flashing momentary day!</br>Now the winds the forest bend,</br>Now the mighty storms descend;</br>Howl the winds, in dreadful song,</br>Yon temple's shadowy ailes among,</br>Hail, sweet horrors, dreadful bliss!</br>What calm can bring a joy like this?—</br>The wind's distress, the thunder's roll,</br>Is music to a life sick soul;</br>The ruin'd vault, or time-worn tow'r,</br>More grateful than a roseate bow'r,</br>Far sweeter than a lover's dream,</br>By myrtle grove or purling stream,</br>And can more calm reflections bring</br>Than all the tributes of the Spring.—

Now at length those horrors cease,</br>The elements are hush'd to peace!</br>See the Moon with silv'ry light</br>Gilds the sadly pleasing night:</br>Step we on where yonder tow'r</br>With iron tongue proclaims the hour.</br>With turfy verdure, lightly prest,</br>The fathers of the village rest:</br>Many a sprightly maid and swain,</br>Whilom fav'rites of the plain,</br>Forego their toils and spotless love</br>To join in guiltless throngs above.</br>Here the milk-maid, wont to greet</br>The dew-rob'd morn with carols sweet;</br>No more the vocal vales repeat</br>Her sylvan love in ditties sweet;</br>Death triumphs o'er her rosy bloom,</br>And oziers bind the decent tomb.—

Here a youth, in early pride,</br>Late another victim died.</br>Oft around the maypole tall</br>Has he led the rural ball;</br>From the lofty mountain's view</br>Oft he stole the morning's dew;</br>Rang'd the haycocks with his hand</br>In a goodly seeming band;</br>The new-wash'd sheep his sheers have shorn,</br>His sickle levell'd fields of corn;</br>Vain boast of sylvan toils, I ween,</br>Since Death's sharp sickle levels him.

Now along the vaulted sky</br>Midnight spirits for mischief fly;</br>Wicked imps, the foes of man,</br>Scatter down their mortal bane.</br>See pale Hecate grimly smile</br>At her antic sister's toil!</br>Hear the instruments of Hell</br>Mutt'ring harsh their horrid spell!</br>Now they mock the wretches moan,</br>Now the charm-rais'd spirits groan;</br>Now the air-play'd cymbals sound,</br>Now they dance their magic round;</br>Swift upon the wings of Night</br>Now they take their gambol'd flight,</br>To their foggy caverns borne,</br>Sick'ning at the breath of Morn.</br>For, soft! behold a distant ray,</br>O'er yonder hill, of grey ey'd Day!</br>The early lark forsakes his bed,</br>And sparrows quit the cottage-shed.</br>The twitt'ring swallow leaves her bow'r,</br>And dew drops glaze the morning flow'r.
Goddess of the pensive mien,</br>Grant me still this solemn scene;</br>Day will wake the sons of Folly,</br>Shade me still, sweet Melancholy!</br>
